episodeTitle: Feudal Era Side Story - Boss Luffy Appears Again
description: In an alternate Edo period Japan, Boss Luffy and his crew enter a mikoshi race with a prize of 1,000,000 belly. They recruit Franky to build their portable shrine while the villainous Thriller Company sabotages rival teams. Brook is found with amnesia, eventually remembering his betrayal by his former Thriller Company allies.

events.title: Mikoshi Race Announced
events.description: In the alternate Edo period Japan setting of Grand Jipangu, a mikoshi (portable shrine) race is announced with a grand prize of 1,000,000 belly. Multiple teams prepare to compete, including Boss Luffy's crew from the Pinwheel Eatery.
events.significance: Sets up the central competition and stakes for this filler arc, establishing the alternate universe setting and the episode's main conflict.

events.title: Boss Luffy Recruits Franky
events.description: Boss Luffy, Usopp, Onami (Nami), and Chopper visit Franky, known as the greatest builder in Grand Jipangu, to construct their mikoshi for the race. Franky accepts the challenge and promises to build them a mikoshi capable of defeating the Thriller Company.
events.significance: Establishes Franky's role in this alternate universe as a master craftsman and sets up the crew's racing strategy. Shows the team's preparation for the competition.

quotes.text: I'll build you a mikoshi good enough to beat the Thriller Company!
quotes.speaker: Franky
quotes.context: Franky accepting the challenge to build a superior mikoshi

events.title: Rival Teams Introduced
events.description: The other participants in the mikoshi race are introduced: The Legendary Flying Fish Riders (led by Duval), the Rolling Express team, and the sinister Thriller Company. Each team has their own mikoshi and racing strategy.
events.significance: Establishes the competition landscape and introduces the episode's antagonists, the Thriller Company, who will serve as the main villains.

events.title: Thriller Company Sabotages Flying Fish Riders
events.description: That night, the Thriller Company attacks The Legendary Flying Fish Riders during practice. Zombies interrupt their training, and Perona appears using her Negative Hollows to demotivate the team. In his resulting self-loathing, team leader Duval destroys their own mikoshi.
events.significance: Demonstrates the Thriller Company's ruthless tactics and willingness to cheat. Shows Perona's devil fruit abilities working in this alternate universe setting.

events.title: Thriller Company Sabotages Rolling Express
events.description: The Thriller Company continues their sabotage campaign by attacking the Rolling Express team's mikoshi. Using Absalom's invisibility powers, they make themselves invisible and destroy the competing team's portable shrine undetected.
events.significance: Further establishes the Thriller Company as cheating villains who will stop at nothing to win. Demonstrates how devil fruit powers function in this alternate universe.

events.title: Brook Found with Amnesia
events.description: While fishing, Usopp accidentally catches Brook and pulls him from the river. Brook is disoriented and suffering from amnesia, unable to remember anything beyond his own name. He discovers a flute stored inside his skull, which serves as a clue to his past.
events.significance: Introduces Brook's role in this episode and creates a mystery about his past connection to the Thriller Company. The amnesia plot device sets up his later memory recovery.

events.title: Pinwheel Eatery's Mikoshi Destroyed
events.description: Boss Luffy's crew returns to the Pinwheel Eatery to find their newly built mikoshi has been destroyed by the Thriller Company. This sabotage threatens their ability to compete in the race and mirrors the attacks on other teams.
events.significance: Raises the stakes for the protagonists and creates urgency. Shows that the Thriller Company views Boss Luffy's team as a serious threat worth sabotaging.

events.title: Brook's Betrayal Revealed
events.description: Upon seeing the destroyed mikoshi, Brook's memories return. He recalls that he was once a member of the Thriller Company but tried to leave the organization. As punishment for his betrayal, Hogback, Perona, and Absalom threw him into the river, where he remained until Usopp found him.
events.significance: Provides Brook's backstory in this alternate universe and explains his amnesia. Establishes his personal motivation to help defeat the Thriller Company and seek revenge for his betrayal.

events.title: Crew Decides to Rebuild and Enter Race
events.description: Despite the destruction of their mikoshi and the Thriller Company's intimidation tactics, Boss Luffy and his crew decide to rebuild their portable shrine and enter the race. Brook joins them in their mission, seeking revenge against his former allies.
events.significance: Demonstrates the crew's determination and unwillingness to be defeated by sabotage. Sets up the climactic race in the next episode and solidifies Brook's alliance with the protagonists.

events.title: Episode Ends on Cliffhanger
events.description: The episode ends with the crew preparing for the mikoshi race, setting up the conclusion in the next episode. This marks the first Boss Luffy special to be a two-part story rather than standalone.
events.significance: Creates anticipation for the race and breaks from the usual Boss Luffy format of self-contained episodes. The cliffhanger ending encourages viewers to watch the conclusion.

quotes.text: I'll build you a mikoshi good enough to beat the Thriller Company!
quotes.speaker: Franky
quotes.context: Accepting the challenge to construct Boss Luffy's racing mikoshi

themes.description: The episode emphasizes determination in the face of unfair obstacles. Despite the Thriller Company's cheating and destruction of their mikoshi, Boss Luffy's crew refuses to give up and commits to rebuilding.
themes.symbolism: The destroyed and rebuilt mikoshi symbolizes resilience and the refusal to be defeated by underhanded tactics.

themes.description: Brook's story arc involves seeking redemption after his failed attempt to leave the Thriller Company. His rescue from the river and alliance with Boss Luffy represents a second chance.
themes.symbolism: Brook being pulled from the water represents rebirth and a fresh start, washing away his past failures.

themes.description: The episode contrasts the Thriller Company's underhanded sabotage tactics with Boss Luffy's crew's honest approach to competition, highlighting themes of fair play and integrity.
themes.symbolism: The mikoshi race represents the conflict between those who win through cheating and those who compete honorably.
culturalReferences: Japanese concepts of honor and bushido

themes.description: This filler arc explores the familiar One Piece characters in a completely different setting and time period, allowing for creative reinterpretation of their personalities and relationships.
themes.symbolism: The Edo period setting provides a cultural lens to examine the same character dynamics in a new context.

characterSpotlights.development: Brook serves as the episode's mystery character, progressing from confused amnesiac to motivated ally seeking revenge against the Thriller Company.

characterSpotlights.development: Boss Luffy demonstrates leadership and resolve, refusing to be intimidated by the Thriller Company's sabotage and rallying his crew to rebuild and compete.

Commits to rebuilding and competing despite setbacks

mangaDifferences.difference: This episode is entirely anime-original filler content with no manga source material. It is based on side stories by Eiichiro Oda but not adapted from the main manga chapters.

trivia.fact: This is the first Boss Luffy Historical Special episode to be part of a two-episode arc rather than a self-contained story. It concludes in Episode 407.
Episode 406 has an IMDb rating of 5.6/10, making it one of the lower-rated episodes in the series, likely due to it being filler content interrupting the main storyline.

sources.title: One Piece - Jidaigeki Tokubetsu Hen: Luffy Oyabun Futatabi Kenzan

trivia.fact: This episode does not include any eyecatchers, breaking from the standard One Piece episode format of the time.
This episode features the final next-episode preview to be narrated in-character. From Episode 407 onward, previews are given by the narrator with Luffy only announcing the title.
The episode uses an alternate 'To Be Continued' end card featuring Japanese characters 'つづく' (tsuzuku) instead of the standard format, emphasizing its two-part nature.

The Boss Luffy Historical Specials were criticized for their timing, with Episodes 406-407 airing right between the intense Sabaody Archipelago arc and the Amazon Lily arc, disrupting narrative momentum.

sources.title: One Piece: 10 Worst Filler Episodes, Ranked

trivia.fact: Despite both featuring Japanese historical settings, the Boss Luffy specials have no connection to the later Wano Country Arc, which was years away when these episodes aired in 2009.
